comment: Teapot soup double boiled conch consommé with black garlic - niceMarble Goby Soon Hock cooked 2 ways - fish is nice & fresh - Steamed with oyster sauce & black fungus - nice- Fried fish with bitter gourd, black beans, tang hoon (mung bean noodles) & vermicelli - very niceDeep fried prawns topped with bonito flakes & Japanese sesame sauce - watermelon base - niceChef Liew's Signature Roasted crispy chicken stuffed with glutinous rice & preserves meats (30 minutes preparation)- nice, glutinous rice is softMSW Durian mochi - Excellent! Super soft skin. Texture is better than Japanese mochi.Fried durian ice cream with avocado sauce - nice

We came here to celebrate my father's birthday, and as it was still within the 15 days of Chinese New Year and covid-19, it was quite a strange experience. Half the restaurant was filled that night. We decided to try the a la carte buffet which included lobsters and some other premium items. I was not sure if it was because we had the buffet or what, but the dishes were not as good as usual.The sea cucumber dish was a disappointment. It looked and tasted strange. Not sure if this was the cause of stomach upset/diarrhea for the 3 of us who tried it. The others did not eat this. In any case, just do not order this dish in the buffet. Service was excellent though. I think it would be better to just order from the regular menu in future.

"Ehhh..." would be a tad dismissive,  but not far off.  I hate to be dismissive of honest efforts, yet there has to be verity in an opinion...especially one posted on Yelp!  The service was attentive enough even though the room was short-staffed for Sunday brunch during the Chinese New Year period...this was before the whole  coronavirus thing had bitten hard.  So bottom line, the wait team was trying, but just couldn't quite make it out of the weeds...and it stayed that way right through dim sum brunch.  The food was truly 3-star with some good ideas, but limited by quality and likely price point.  The dim sum was substantial, but didn't quite hit the mark when it came to texture and/or seasoning.   There were quite a few salty items and some of the steamed items were just this side of dry or rubbery.  The standout for me was a lightly deep-fried tofu dish dusted with Himalayan pink salt.  It was simple, showed restraint, and demonstrated an understanding and familiarity with each and every component of the dish.  I'm going to take a stab in the dark here and guess the food cost for really good salt and really good tofu came in under the unbending Limbo pole of a brunch budget at Peony Jade. So to sum it up, the brunch menu at Peony Jade had me going back for another bite...but not in a good way.  Each bite left me hanging a little, just shy of pleasingly sated. Great meals are less about more and almost always  about balance, which in Peony Jade's case was poignantly missing from the brunch menu.

Recently, Peony Jade has received the Michelin Guide's Bib Gourmand award, offering "exceptional good food at moderate prices". Naturally, given Singaporeans' favourite past time of arguing about food, there has been a lot of controversy of this. So I thought it would be a good time to leave a review for this place (especially given that there's only 2 others, one each in 2015 and 2016 - I might as well fulfill the quota for 2016), which celebrates its 12th anniversary in the Keppel Club this year.In short, the award was deserved as most of the dishes are good or excellent, and the prices are quite reasonable (even before the credit card discount). Furthermore, this place doesn't just serve traditional Chinese food, but has subtle spins on it that adapt it to a modern sensibility. For example, there are animal shaped buns to appeal to the kids, and there are some Western ingredients and techniques (and no, not the usual foie gras that so many places rely on).The Rose-Infused Honey Glazed BBQ Pork was wonderful. Most char siew (BBQ Pork) is made with meat that is rather lean, leaving it rather dry and gaining more flavour from its sauce than its inherent characteristics. The BBQ pork here had lots of fat and so was really tender and succulent. The fragrant sauce worked in harmony with the meat rather than being the main deliverer of flavour to the dish. I didn't taste the rose, but I was still really happy with this.We also had Szechuan Style Tea Smoked Duck. This was pretty good, being crispy with a subtle tea taste. It was served with a hoisin-like sauce that was probably fermented bean sauce, as well as steamed buns. Not the usual serving method but some might appreciate the different take on the dish.The beef tenderloin cubes with scallions and premium sauce was possibly the best dish of all. The cut was pretty good, and could pass for good wagyu, with delicious fat and marbling. The sauce was fragrant and robust and the wok hei (kiss of the wok) was really great.The pork tenderloin with XO sauce and snow peas was not bad. The meat was tender and bouncy and the snow peas were remarkably clean-tasting (either due to freshness, not being over-fried or both).The stewed wintermelon with crabmeat and roe was alright. Nothing special, but a bit pricey due to the crab. So it is best avoided.The dry beef hor fun was very fragrant. The beef was tender and had bite, even though it was not primarily a beef dish. The noodles also had wok hei.We also had crispy youtiao roulette with king prawns. This dish is so awesome that I've ordered it on all 3 of my visits this year. The name is a bit of a misnomer because the very generous, fresh and flavourful prawn interior is surrounded by fried beancurd skin rather than youtiao (dough fritter). It is then wrapped with chee cheong fun (on the thick side) and served with a light soya sauce based sauce (the sort you usually find with dim sum chee cheong fun, not the breakfast vegetarian chee cheong fun thick sweet black sauce).On 2 previous visits we had sweet and sour sticky pork ribs. The sauce was better than that of the usual Emperor/King Pork Ribs - it was based on that standard flavour, but taken further and elaborated. Furthermore, they were sticky ribs - inspired by US-style ribs (instead of being wetter like Chinese style Emperor/King Pork Ribs are).We also had deep fried cod pieces in an edible basket tossed with dried chilis. This wasn't too bad - reasonably crispy and fresh. The chilis' flavour didn't really come through, which wasn't necessarily bad as our pre-schooler could eat the bits not buried in the dried chilis.The siu mai and soya sauce chicken were normal. On the other hand, the shredded duck salad (something you wouldn't find at virtually all other Chinese restaurants) was a bit uninspired. It didn't have much duck, and the salad dressing was boring. So no not everything here is very good, or even good.

Family had our CNY dinner here and my father-in-law ordered their set dinner. I must say that everything was lovely! The set menu included:1) Yu Sheng2) Shark's Fin Soup3) Steamed Fish in Soy Sauce4) Roasted Chicken5) Prawns in XO Sauce6) Broccoli with Abalone 7) Seafood Fried Rice8) Orh Nee & Nian Gao Service is great and the taste is incredible. It's Chinese cuisine on fine dining standards.

Came here for dim sum and it was alright, nothing was that great or that bad. We ate til we were stuffed with the ala carte menu and had tea. The cost was around $90 for 2 people. The staff was not smiling but they were attentive and professional. We'll probably come back as they are close to us and the service was decent and cost not too bad.

I had been wanting to try out the rainbow cakes at The Bakery Chef for over a year now! And I finally got there! There's HDB parking at the nearby library, which is gantry operated.It is quite a small cafe, not a lot of seats, and they do not take reservations either. The cake display is so inviting! I had to order the $5.80 rainbow cake for sure and it did not disappoint! The bakery chef has started to sell waffles recently as well and I decided to try a non-conventional waffle with cotton candy!1. Rainbow cake $5.80The was moist, the layers were of even thickness and most of all! The butter cream on the top wasn't sweet. It was perfect. I loved it! I would totally get this again for sure!  I like that it is a petite size, so it's not too huge that you have to share it and also makes the price cheaper as well :D2. Berries Waffle $13.90The waffles came with cotton candy perched on a plastic stick that was "planted" into a cup of green tea powder on top of a cup of chocolate mousse. The waffles were very crispy and I loved it! They were generous with the fruits and I am won over by their crispy waffles.I also like that they have free wifi! The staff were friendly, but the shop is really cramped, and the tables are very close to each other. Nonetheless, if you are within the area, do check this out :D

I had a chance to try out the Rainbow Cake. Not to shabby, it has sparing amount of nuts. My latte had a cute "nyan-nyan" cat, which I really liked as well. It's a pity that the electrical sockets were covered, so I had to proceed to the library nearby to work on my laptop.Oh! And for $10 you can get a Rainbow Cake, a Cuppa and a Macaron. Makes for a good tea, or a dessert after Lunch!

With the radio in the background, you can easily feel like home in this comfy and hidden bakery. It's quite small (around 15 persons inside and 6 outside) but it worth definitely a good place in my "where to sit down with my computer" quest. I unfortunately didn't try their rainbow cake or waffles but I think it's a perfect excuse to come back.

Situated along the road near Bukit Merah Central, it's quite hard to miss this place when you're around that area. My colleagues and I decided to try out this one after reading some reviews on Instagram. We were instantly greeted by the friendly staffs upon arrival; probably because we were the first ones there. Haha! The cafe was soon filled by the time we got our order.I tried 2 different cakes -- Rainbow Cake and Chocolate Guanaja... The rainbow cake, nuh uh! Not so much. At least I have tasted better. But the chocolate cake, muah!! Me likey! They had many more pretty looking cakes which I wish I could have tried given the time.My colleagues tried their Apple Caramel Pancake and both their feedbacks were the same, "The apples are too overwhelming!" So well, I still would like to try more of their stuffs though. Overall, quite an experience.

I've heard quite a lot about the Bakery Chef ever since I came back from Tokyo but I've never got the motivation to head to the main shop. So it must be luck and fate that I chanced upon its pop-up stall at Orchard Central. The signature rainbow cake dutifully lived up to its reputation and exemplified all the essential qualities of a good sponge; moist and fluffy. There is even a tinge of citrus embedded in the layers. However, the cream was frosted unevenly and in short supply compared to the previous photos of rainbow cakes churned out from the same kitchen. The Chocolate Rainbow  ($5.50) turned out to be the better executed of the two as the ganache was velvety and the bottom sponge layers did not suffer from the ill fate of dehydration like the Rainbow Cake did. Most of the cakes assumed the same style and formula; squarish sponge cakes layered with cream. There isn't much excitement until I had the Matcha and Caramel Delight ($5.50 each), whose core is injected with red bean paste and salted caramel sauce respectively.Alas, something unpredicted amidst the predictabilities. In fact, both cakes surpassed the excellency of the predecessors with their unmistakable saturated sponge and little mounds of smoky piped cream. Nonetheless, these cakes were extremely delicate and I counted my blessings that little damage was inflicted by the heat when I transported them home. However, it was only until the Praline Delight ($6) when I started to see potential of this pastry shop. Chocolate mousse, hazelnut paste +crunch, sponge cake coated in chocolate ganache and nuts. It might not be the most original idea, but it's a classic combination done well. Simply look at how beautiful each layer has come together! This cake should deserve more credit and raving reviews than the mundane sponge cakes.

One of the better dessert cafe in Singapore. Even though the cafe is located in a Neighbourhood area, it is flocking with lots of customer daily. Their dessert is amazing such that after you eat you would want to have another one. The atmosphere is great for relaxing or gathering with friends. However it is small and crowded most of the times. There are out door seating available too. But it gets hot outside. So I would recommend to go during off peak period. Must try their waffles as well as their cakes. Delicious. They do customer cake orders on their website. Really amazing cafe.

I've tried about 8 cakes from this place and I've yet to find one I dislike.If you like rainbow cakes, this is the place to go. Instagram-worthy cakes here, at wallet-friendly prices, with good coffee (as reviewed by a colleague). My favorite has to be the red velvet cheesecake, although chocolate lovers will revel in the chocolate cake selection.Please do come here and support them. I think they are a nice small, cosy establishment with really good cakes that are worth every dollar.

Nice place to relax and enjoy a great slice of cake. Try many different kinds of cakes, waffles and brownies! it taste amazing! definitely worth to come! Bring a book and enjoy a day reading at the place. p.s the place is a little small but it's worth it!

It has very nice chocolate fudge indulgence cake and carrot cake which are both like... Godzilla cakes due to their size! Lol! The carrot cake is really one of the best ones I have tried around town as it is not too sweet.

address: 2 Science Park Dr #01-27 Ascent Singapore 118222 Singapore
comment: Another restaurant on Burpple Beyond membership. Self service style. Order at counter. Pick up food at counter when buzzer rings. No GST or service charge. Help yourself to water at counter.Cioppino Fisherman's Stew (S$11.90)Yellowtail, Barramundi, Clams, Prawns, Tomatoes, Fennel, Pumpkin, RouilleOrdered this alone at first but it was not filling for a main. The seafood was quite juicy.Truffled Carbonara Spaghetti (S$11.90)Streaky Bacon, Fresh Mushroom Cream Sauce, Sous-vide EggSmell not bad of truffle. The sauce was quite rich and egg was cooked just right with the lava yolk flowing out.Portuguese Baked Rice (S$11.90)Sous-vide Chicken Breast, Mild Curry Veloute, Carrots, Onions, Mozzarella CheeseNice and cheesy rice with tender chicken meat.Australian Grain-Fed Beef Short Rib (S$18.90)220gram, Sauteed Garden Vegetables, Garlic Mashed Potatoes, Veal JusThe meat was quite tender. Like that the potatoes was soft and chucky. Showed that it was using real potatoes, not powdered version.

Had the beer batter fish at Morgan field's knowing that they are good at meat I tried something different. Their fish is very crispy and not oily. Every bite has a crunch feeling. The lunch promotion is worth it as it comes with a soup ...

Since it was weekday lunch time, I decided to get the top value lunch set which was available usually weekday from 11am to 3pm.Grilled Pork Chops (S$16.90++)BBQ glazed pork chop, tender & juicy, this is bound to make you salivate thinking about it. Served with Roasted Potatoes & Garden Salad.Came with a choice of drink and soup.The soup was potato soup. While savoury, there's barely any potato bits in it.For drink, selected ice lemon tea which was not too sweet.The meat was quite tender although felt that the BBQ sauce was a bit too overpowering. Serving was quite filling that one could not finish the potato and greens.Service was not bad , with the staff offering wet tissue at the end of the meal to clean up.

address: 10 Bukit Chermin Rd Level 3, Keppel Club Singapore 109918 Singapore
comment: The food was rather good here (the beef rendang is delicious and the meat is super tender) and the setting at the golf club is just beautiful. The service was rather slow, but it was a busy night. However, I was really impressed with one waitress. I had gotten a crispy piece of rice stuck in my teeth, and I was trying to discreetly push it out using my tongue. My host didn't even notice that I was trying to get out the piece of rice, but a waitress came over (without me having to ask) and gave me some toothpicks. I was super impressed with the fact that she noticed something so small and made the effort to make me more comfortable.

address: 10 Bukit Chermin Rd Level 3, Keppel Club Singapore 109918 Singapore
comment: Special Thanks to Colleague who had introduced this place for lunch. Never did i know that there is a hidden gem within the area of a country club. I always have the mindset that anything in the club is only exclusively for members and not the public but this is not the case.Talking about PeraMakan, it excites me as Peranakan Food is not commonly found and even if so it's only the few that we have been visiting.Starters for the Peranakan Cuisine is none other than their Ngoh Hiang. Meat with prawns were rolled and deeply fried. There were 3 rolls and they were all cut into 12 pieces, easiler to paired with the sweet sauce or a saucer filled with chilli, black sauce and Luak Chye.Nyonya Ngoh Hiang - $12I felt that Buah Keluak makes Peranakan Cuisine outstanding in the sense that I have not come across other cuisine making use of this Indonesian black nut as part of their dishes ingredient. Chicken was braised and soften among the richness of the black nut and Garam Assam Gravy. It might taste on a salty side if you are having just the dish alone without any plain rice. Do note that Steam Rice are served at $1 per head and refillable.For those who love Buah Keluak, each serving only comes with 2 nuts and special spoons were given to retrieve the flesh in the nuts.Ayam Buah Keluak - $16Braising in yummy tau cheo gravy, the dish was awesome. Pork belly was cooked with dried shitake mushrooms and winter bamboo shoots too. Presentation was dull in colors initially but was brightened up by the used of green chilli as garnishings.Babi Pongtay - $14The default order that cannot be skip during a Pernakan Cuisine! Simply loves its braised vegetables coupled with dried ingredients in bean sauce.Nyonya Chap Chye - $10The last to be served will be their red snapper fish head cooked in Nyonya Curry. Curry gravy was very appetizing indeed and makes a perfect pairing to the white rice. Assorted vegetables like egg plant, lady's finger and tomato among the items in the curry. Fish head was relatively fresh and was pleasing to the tastebuds.Nyonya Curry Fish Head - $28There can never be short of the taste of Gula Melaka here in their Chendol. Our desserts were shared among 5 of us and it was not a bad idea too. With freshly squeeze coconut milk over shaved ice with chendol strips and kidney beans, its all what you can find all in a bowl of chendol.Chendol - $5Buboh Cha Cha can be served either hot or cold, depending on your liking. The best thing is that freshly squeezed coconut milk was used and was good with yams, sweetpotatpes cubes that was steamed to its softened form, not forgettging my favourite tapioca jujubes!Buboh Cha Cha - $5Desserts for Durians lovers! Serve in a plate of 4. These choux pastry was filled with delicious D24 durian mousse. Taste was good but if they can come in chilled form, it would be perfect.Durian Puffs - $6Knowing that Peranakan dishes are never too easy to prepare and requires alot of perparation, they were always priced at a dearer side, that includes dining in PeraMakan. However, I find that the cuisine serve here is rather authentic and was not too commercialized like other places. However for parking, it may cost a bomb and you might want to take note.

address: 10 Bukit Chermin Rd Level 3, Keppel Club Singapore 109918 Singapore
comment: Food is pretty good. Beef rendang and curry chicken is highly recommended. Chili kang Kong also a must try. Only if it is not so pricey  also like Keppel club for it's relax atmosphere. Will return for sure.

address: 10 Bukit Chermin Rd Level 3, Keppel Club Singapore 109918 Singapore
comment: Super expensive, but the staff is attentive and accommodating. The food just OK. Not worth the drive all the way out there.

address: 10 Bukit Chermin Rd Level 3, Keppel Club Singapore 109918 Singapore
comment: Is that a whole lamb shank, served on the bone? Why yes it is! Is the entire thing slathered in rendang sauce? Why yes it is!Is it amazingly delicious? Okay I can't keep up the cheerleading, but you bet it is!They have so many of your Nonya favourites, including one of my number one picks: chap chye. Okay lah, it's a cop out dish, but I REALLY like this one. And the otah's pretty good too. It comes in an oval dish, and it's chock full of fish meat and prawns - real ingredients! The free-flow rice doesn't hurt either, so eat your fill!Save a little room for dessert. The gula melaka sago is surprising! They've cleverly cooked the sago, and then let it set in little containers, and then popped it out when its cool, and voila! Sago in a jelly mould! A fun little touch. Dousing it all in gula melaka ain't bad.

address: 10 Bukit Chermin Rd Level 3, Keppel Club Singapore 109918 Singapore
comment: This is the place we come to when we don't feel like competing for parking and the dinner crowd at Ivins. Food : IMO not as fantastic as Ivins but good enough. I guess PeraMakan is a bit more refined in its presentation and preparation but they don't have pong tauhu here, only bakwan kepiting and hee peow (fish maw) soup. The portions aren't as generous but I guess it's quite decent as well. I quite like the Nyonya chap chye and the udang masak kuah nanas (prawns in pineapple gravy) as well as the otak. Ambience : Family styled but also a place you can go to for business lunches. Makes sense since it's located in Keppel Club. Bring a jacket / shawl, air conditioning can get a bit chilly.Service : Quite decentDifficult to get out of here unless you drive. Taxi can take ages especially in the evenings.

address: 10 Bukit Chermin Rd Level 3, Keppel Club Singapore 109918 Singapore
comment: Very good. Peramakan is one of the best Peramakan places that I have ever tried in Singapore. The ayam buah Keluak is out of this world!

This place has a really great, intimate setting for a romantic dinner or anniversary celebration. And I would say that price-wise, it's not out of the reach of most people (even NUS students come here occasionally).I love the ravioli they dish out here, pair it with red or white wine. Particularly, choose the salmon cream sauce that I feel is the best of the lot. Other things to try on the menu are the Salmon carpaccio which helps kickstart your appetite nicely, and the carbonara.

address: 321 Alexandra Rd #01-17, Alexandra Central Singapore 159964 Singapore
comment: I always wanted try Toast Box - authentic toast set which comes with grain toast topped with pork powder and 2 eggs (20% cooked).  Another dish is laksa.  Laksa is like noodle soup based with coconut milk.  First time trying it and I love it.Also their coffee is very famous.  Very dark and rich taste.Toast Box satisfied my cravings in one visit. Toast Box in Singapore is a fast-food chain restaurant  specializes in toast and coffee.If you are not familiar with Toast Box..  need to try it.   Will not be disappointed.

address: 29 Heng Mui Keng Terrace #06-21 Singapore 119620 Singapore
comment: Quiet hospitality, tasty Peranakan food. During the 16th and 17th century, Chinese young men went to Singapore, Malaysia and Indonesia to find their fortune. They intermarried with non-Muslim women, birthing the Peranakan culture which has its own unique cuisine. One the of most unique ingredients they use in this food is the buah keluak or Pangium Edule seed. It is actually a poisonous seed that needs to be buried after harvesting to leach the toxins. However, the delicious, nutty, slightly bitter savory and soft flesh inside when cooked in a rich gravy is amazing. Chili Padi does a nice job picking, choosing good sized seeds that are not to old.The Ngoh Hiang or mined pork wrapped and deep fried in tofu skin also has a nice texture and is served with a slightly sweet sauce. Order the Bakwang Kepiting, a soup with meatballs. The broth is delicate and the meatballs, pretty good. I enjoyed eating it with their mild sambal belacan, chili sauce made with fermented shrimp and red chilies. Yum!The Chap Chye, braised mixed vegetables and Egg Foo Yong were okay, but not memorable.Desserts we tried included the Chendol and the Sago Pudding. Both were okay. If you have a sweet tooth, ask for extra Gula Melaka or palm sugar in syrup form.I enjoyed my experience at Chili Padi.

address: 29 Heng Mui Keng Terrace #06-21 Singapore 119620 Singapore
comment: What happened to the Ayam Buah Keluak???The nut meat which was velvety and nutty tasted like they were soaked in sugar water! Robbing me of the bitter, pungent, dark chocolate tang like experience. The prices are exorbitant,  and the portions small. So for the kitchen to screw up the headliner of the meal was deeply disappointing. I sulked away and pacified my frustration the next morning with a delightful Rawon from Bedok South.

address: 29 Heng Mui Keng Terrace #06-21 Singapore 119620 Singapore
comment: For a $20 per person lunch buffet, there was a laksa station, kueh counter, kueh pie tee station and cooked food with dishes like rendang and pork belly buns. The quality of the food here is not very good, and I wouldn't come here specially for a buffet or lunch. Nothing was bad or very good, but service was prompt and it can accommodate about 100 people, which was why we had a corporate lunch here. You best call for a cab if you didn't drive. There aren't many taxis around this part of NUS!

address: 29 Heng Mui Keng Terrace #06-21 Singapore 119620 Singapore
comment: will not bother to go if not for my friend who wanted to try nonya food.  The front server was so rude to us and practically said the price loud to us several times while rolling her eyes. As my friend was visiting, I was just going to leave it. Worst part was when I was taking food at the buffet line, another server push me aside to grab the dish plate. As I was talking to my friend about it, the same server came by with her cart and knocked into my chair without apologising. Food was way too salty and not authentic as described. Don't waste money and time, go somewhere else. PS: their laksa fish cake and chendol coconut milk turned bad, it was sour and yet they still served it. there wasn't many people when we went there and I know the reason.

address: 29 Heng Mui Keng Terrace #06-21 Singapore 119620 Singapore
comment: Yelp has no classification for the food of the culture of Peranakan.  What is it?  It's a bit of south east asia.  It's a bit Malay.  It's a bit Chinese.  It's totally Singapore.  And here, it's in buffet form.  What I liked about this buffet is it's DIY (Do it yourself).  Many of the dishes are there in their elements and you put it together.  Laksa, MeeSaim, BBQ meat buns.  All off it there to adjust to your spice and taste level and it's a bit fresher than sitting out in a normal buffet line.  Course you can't complain to the chef if you don't like it because you kinda made it.  What I thought was fun was experimenting and making my own Peranakan fusions (like putting the stewed beef inside the steamed buns).  Fun indeed.

I like this place for the convenience and healthy options. The portions are good and it could last me till late dinner. If you're looking to eat something healthy and clean, this is the place for you. Though I would say that it is a little pricey for salad bowls.

As someone who is usually skeptical of salads being a meal, this is one of my favorite salad places!! For the basic salad you can choose one protein, one complex carb and 3 additions (unfortunately extra charge for avocado) but they are pretty generous with their portions. The few knocks against them is that their protein is really inconsistent. One day the steak is perfect and the next it can be rare cooked with a lot of fat. I have found that the less crowded they are, and the further away you are from their opening hour (11) the more likely you are to get quality. Otherwise this place is healthy and fills me up unlike most salad lunch places!

Delicious and filling. I'm not much of a salad person since it usually makes me hungry fast, but The Daily Cut offers options like quinoa and sweet potato that are filling. The protein options are plenty and the portion is big. The dressings taste good too, and you can take as much as you want. When I feel like eating healthy I usually go here. So far I have not been disappointed.

Brunch / breakfast place in Fusionopolis. Dishes here come with egg and bread - you can choose to customize what you want in the plate or choose one of the many delicious pre-designed options. The food here tastes simple, healthy and good. Would definitely recommend if you are looking for brunch / all-day-breakfast in the area.

I love this place simply for the fact that they make their own bread! As you walk in on your right, you see massive glass doors that lead into the kitchen. They have huge mixer bowls and all sorts of fancy, commercial grade baking equipment.They sell their bread too, you can buy half a loaf for $4-5 or a whole loaf for $8.They have free wifi, water, and baking magazines to browse through. You order at the counter and for sandwich items, you pick them up at the collection counter when your buzzer rings. For breakfast platters and other non-sandwich items, the staff will serve the food to you. Everything on their menu is nett priced and sounds and looks delicious!1. Smoked Chicken Sandwich $8Sandwiched in a very crispy country bread, are smoked chicken slices, long beans, mustard and melted cheese. The exterior of the bread is almost biscuit like and it does take some jaw muscle to bite in. The chicken slices are breast meat sort of, with the mustard and gooey melted cheese. The chicken tasted so good! The smoked flavour wasn't very evident, mostly covered up by the mustard. The long beans provided as crunch in the sandwich as well as the "green" for the sandwich.

A hidden gem (can I still say this? It's getting less and less hidden by the week!) in the currently low traffic Galaxis. Prices are very reasonable, and the coffee, breads, pancakes and dessert are fantastic. The sandwiches are decent but not outstanding.The flat white in particular is executed skillfully, with a roast that isn't too acidic, topped off with smooth, creamy microfoam.The wife enjoyed the sweet pepper vegetarian sandwich while my toddler who's been having a bad week cheerily gobbled down the classic scrambled eggs on toast (rye bread).The butterscotch & berries pancakes were soft and fluffy (get this!), and we couldn't get enough of the banana coconut bread pudding with gula melaka caramel and vanilla ice cream (get this too!)Give the cookies a miss though - they were dry (we prefer soft and gooey) and were a tad too sweet.

The coffee here is pretty legendary. Its gentle flavor with a hint of nuttiness swaddles your tongue in warm dulcet tones, leaving you wanting more. Its the kind of coffee you'd want to being home to meet your parents, and they wouldn't even ask all the normal embarrassing questions because its personality is just that charming. And then you'd get married, it'd be a simple wedding, with just a few guests, and you'd wake up every morning wondering what you did to deserve such a good coffee. And then you'll have kids, and it'd be the cutest little cappuccino ever, and your life will be perfect. And then one day, you'll wake up in horror to find that you've drunk your little cappucino, brown stains still around your mouth as they drag you away to jail, kicking and screaming about how it was just one sip.Oh and the bread pudding is pretty great too. More like that girl whos kind of cute with the funky hair that youd hang out with a few times but overall not too bad either.

Wow this place is NOT good. Ive been using Yelp since 2010 especially when I moved to a new continent to help eliminate trial and error. It's not often that I get disappointed by highly rated yelp and this is one of them rare instances.We ordered the butterscotch & berries pancake and a Norwegian. The pancake was average and the Norwegian was a disappointment. For me salad (came w the Norwegian) isn't just a garnish, it's food. The cucumber was seeded (ok) and hard (not ok), the hollandaise sauce that came w the poached egg was not impressive (watery). The Hokkaido bread was quite ok. The smoked salmon was v average. The grilled asparagus on the other hand was really good. Unfortunately that's forms only 5-10% of the dish.The service was pretty good and people are Super friendly. Alight I'll bump them up to 3.

The pancakes were an absolute delight! I don't typically enjoy pancakes because they tend to be too sweet for my liking, but I tried the maple syrup with bacon (forgot the name) and it was not too sweet and not too salty! The bacon was also one of best I've tried. The sandwich was pretty normal, but the pork belly sandwich was interesting - it's like a Chinese and western fusion. Pretty cool place, everyone working there seemed to be students, and I heard it's a relatively new place so many things were amateur eg paper plates and amateur waiters (we were asked to sit with a bunch of strangers on the same table before we hesitated and they gave us a table of our own). Not too expensive and the portion was alright.

5-stars for the price for value at Bread Yard. You can construct your own Egg's Benny for under $10 ($6 for poached eggs with Hollandaise sauce + $2-3 for either back bacon or smoked salmon). I would say the bacon is a better bet than the salmon--the latter was a bit salty the last time I had it. Sandwiches are also passable, while the mashed potatoes with gravy were delicious! Home-brewed iced team should be skipped.Seating is often easy to come by, but the space is small. Bread Yard is tucked away inside one north, but it's a comfy place on a Sunday morning or afternoon. Take a walk around to catch a glimpse of the architectural work of the late Zaha Hadid!
I really wanted to like this place, but sadness. My coffee was burnt and undrinkable. My croissantwich was dry and room temperature. The staff seems pleasant though.

I love their coffee. I usually get their iced latte (or iced mocha - it is powder based and not sweet - if I am feeling like an afternoon pick me up). Their sandwiches are quick and easy for in between classes at INSEAD.

1) Food is fresh.2) There's a queue but it moves quite fast.3) Items I recommend: The large intestines and pork liver are done really well. The otah. Fish of various sizes. Chap chye. Mui Chye is not too salty and it's tender. Hae Bee Hiam (fresh and must be made inhouse). Chye Poh egg (if it's not sold out). Fish cake if you can get it. Order extra bowls of porridge upfront rather than deal with queuing up again.4) That's the con, sometimes you come at 8pm and some popular items are sold out. Maybe we were in between batches since this place serves till early morning. It's apparently a fave haunt of taxi drivers and also my durian guy...who told me about it.5) Help yourself to chilli at the side, there's a giant bowl of it.6) After you order, your dishes are placed on a big metal tray on a side table. You pay and self-collect.7) It seems to have gotten more expensive recently but compare it with Joo Hin which is probably more expensive, I prefer here as it's a bit lighter all round which is the point of porridge for me.One pet peeve, the tables here aren't very cleaned up after the previous customer goes.

There are tons of reviews of this porridge stall in google and other food blogs. As soon as you enter the car park during lunch hours you will notice many taxis... This is testament enough of its fame.The porridge isn't too hot. It serves mildly sticky and mildly watery porridge. It's the Teochew kind, as its name suggests. The array of dishes available is just so amazing. We ordered so many varieties and so many dishes that we didn't thought we could finish! But we did... We ordered in faith of its reputation for low prices. And yes indeed from the pictures I posted all in all including drinks we only paid around 68 bucks. Eat-all-you-want-without-guilt nor hole in your pocket.

Ye Shanghai, a favourite hotspot for taxi drivers as well as my place for affordable and comfortable Teochew Mui whenever I'm in that vincity. Their porridge is well-liked by young and old, just look at the queue. But dont worry, the team of helpers at Ye Shanghai was rather efficient in their operations.All in all, Ye Shanghai serves a value for money dinner especially when we talked about Teochew Mui. Their competitor in the same vicinity whom sell the similar items may cost twice as much. Therefore, they are always my first choice for budget meal.

I've come here twice now, and each time it's been solid. I hesitate to say amazing, and that's not to say it isn't... so I'm giving it four stars for now.The first time it was close to midnight, and I ate with two friends who were ravenous - we had about 6 dishes (favourites like duck, chai por omelette, salted veg, salted egg and one or two more) among us and we barely hit $20.The more recent time I went, I was less hungry, so we ordered 2-person portions for three of us, and for seven dishes, we paid... GET THIS: $12.80!!! We ordered quite similar dishes, and had beancurd skin and pork belly instead of duck, but how did we end up paying only $12.80? I'll never know.The set up is super efficient - one dude goes up the line asking for your rice/porridge orders, and sets the tray in front of the the guy who dishes out the... dishes. Now this guy is a robot. You point, and he plates. And plates. And plates. Until you stop pointing. Then another guy tallies your bill, and walks you to the cashier, who tells you whatever number the other guys tells him. You pay. And you sit and eat.Great system, good food, AMAZING prices. So why only four stars? I'm thinking... I prefer the quality of food at Lim Joo Hin along Havelock Road... but I'm slowly being convinced of the merits of this place. For one... I might be paying half of what I'd be paying at LJH!
They serve home cooked food at really affordable prices. And the food tastes good! My come-to place for my Teochew muay fix.

My favorite Teochew porridge place. Wide selection of dishes but it isn't cheap anymore. It was used to be very cheap. It used to cost $12 for 8 dishes but it almost $20 for the same number of dishes. I hate queuing so the saving grace - the grumpy uncle. The grumpy uncle, who probably scooped a few tonnes of food for customers for the past hour, can clear the queue relatively fast. You can decide to have porridge or rice with their braised sauce.

very bad service from the boss (business owner)! when he was around, the staff gave much smaller serving sizes. when this issue was raised to him, he got cocky and asked customers to eat elsewhere if they are not happy. there are other better places to eat without having to deal with his poor attitude! food is not what it is used to be compared to the old location anyway.
Fresh and well seasoned and delicious! Excellent price and quality! Recommended by a taxi driver and he was raving about it in the car and I can totally understand why now. Thank you.

address: 56 Tanglin Rd #B1-01, Tanglin Post Office Singapore 247964 Singapore
comment: First time here and its simply awesome!! If you want good and quality food that comes with great service, this is the place! Their hokkaido scallop tartar is really good! My spouse and i had our wedding anniversary lunch here and their special menu is unique. Turkey werent like the regular ones and salmon was really good.

address: 56 Tanglin Rd #B1-01, Tanglin Post Office Singapore 247964 Singapore
comment: Arrived for their weekday lunch set ($15 for 2 courses, $18 for 3 courses). They gave us a table indoors although it seemed to have been fully booked that afternoon (when we left they were still a couple of tables empty but with a reserved sign).Service was welcoming - I had warm water served in a tea cup (a first for me) - and overly friendly. We placed our orders and were told that the pork collar udon wasn't available and in its place was a prawn pasta. The starter, an onsen tamago arrived swiftly. Subsequently the mains arrived too. I paid $5 to change my mains to the yaniniku beef with caramelised pumpkin rice cake. The beef was fine, but I have an issue with the rice cake. Are "caramelised" and "cake" synonyms for tough and overcooked shaped rice? Was the rice overnight and not heated up fully? I had a tummy ache after the meal for 2 days. I hope it wasn't due to the "rice cake".After we paid and left, I looked through the receipt while trying to split the bill among my lunch partners, then we realized that the prawn pasta had a surcharge of $3 that wasn't communicated to us. We went back to clarify but they left it at that. This is very sneaky and there were no apologies for it. Will not go back.

address: 56 Tanglin Rd #B1-01, Tanglin Post Office Singapore 247964 Singapore
comment: I went there for lunch last week, $15 for a 2 course. Definitely worth it for the taste and presentation. Impressive!

address: 56 Tanglin Rd #B1-01, Tanglin Post Office Singapore 247964 Singapore
comment: Overpriced, bad service, and the only thing worse is the food. Only visit if you want to destroy your evening / day.

address: 1 Queensway #03-51 Queensway Shopping Centre Singapore 149053 Singapore
comment: I like this place! Forget what you see about the webpage of this place - come here for a buffet! Came here with colleagues on a weekday for lunch, and we all looked at the online menu beforehand, and I wanted to get a kimchi jjigae for about $15, and the moment I saw a poster saying that their table barbecue buffet was $16++, ala carte was out of my mind.They have a decent range of acceptable meats, with beef, chicken, squid, pork belly, bacon, and a whole range of banchan, some fried rice, rice cakes, seaweed soup, kimchi soup, and ginseng chicken soup.The quality of food here isn't top notch, but it generally is okay. Don't be fussy, come here for volume and value, not 5* quality. Service is soso, but what do you expect - this costs practically nothing.

Excellent tempura dishes with just the right amount of batter and fresh ingredients. I enjoy sitting at the counter as it completes the experience. The set lunches are good value albeit on the expensive side - this is at the Regent!Service has been uniformly excellent and attentive.

Haven't been here for a long long time. Tempura is still good.Looks like the prices are lower, not cheaper. Less tempura at lower prices. Highest lunch set is $75. Just enough food.This set has prawns with prawn heads, vegetables and fish. Also comes with a bowl of rice with chopped up prawns and a generous sprinkling of sesame seeds.Still a good meal after all these years.Tempura here is lightly coated with batter so you can taste the food and not just the batter.

I have never tried the full tempura course in Tenshin but I am a big fan of their special tendon donburi. It's basically donburi served with a tempura of prawn, anago, maitake mushroom (dat umami!) and prawn kakiage. I'm a fan of simple dish done well and Tenshin achieves just that.
Specialises in Tempura. The batter is just right with pretty good service.

address: 1 Maritime Square #01-64, HarbourFront Centre Singapore 099253 Singapore
comment: Located inside the santosa resort close to the university studio.  It's a the Disney walkway with many shops and restaurants Needed a place to sit and rest Foods and drinks are ok, but staff is rude and unfriendly not willing to serve.

address: 1 Maritime Square #01-64, HarbourFront Centre Singapore 099253 Singapore
comment: It was late afternoon and the place was relatively quiet. The place was packed with guys surrounding the big screen which was showing F1 live at malaysia. There was both indoor and outdoor dine in area. With so many customers, there was only 2 service staffs around. We helped ourselves to a table and the menus from the counter as the staffs were too busy.Amigo Nachos ($18)Corn chips loaded with homemade chilli beef, baked with mozzarella. Dip into accompanying guacamole and cheese for an extra punch.The dish was different from the picture on the menu. The chilli beef was not served on top of the chip. There was no mozzarella on the chip. The chilli beef was quite watered down. Felt kind of cheated here.The Harry's Seven ($36.90)Harry's Signature Wings, Chicken Satay, Spicy Chicken Sausage, Otah Toasties, Onion Rings, Fish Cracklings and Crisps.The wing was a tab too dry. The satay was more on the sweet side. The onion ring was a tab too hard. The otah toasties which looked dry and hard, actually tasted not bad except that there was only 2 pieces.Grilled Tuna Steak ($24)Served with aromatic tomato sauce, black olives, bell peppers and creamy mash.The fish was a tab dry and overcooked. Lucky there was a lot of sauce to help it.Sticky Date Toffee Pudding ($14)Warm, sweet sticky date pudding with toffee sauce, served alongside drizzled vanilla ice cream.Although I could not taste the date in the pudding, the pudding was moist and hot, and went quite well with the ice cold vanilla ice cream.Peach Cooler ($8)A sweet concoction of peach slices and mint leaves topped with soda.Lemon Lime Bitters ($8)Lemonade, lime cordial and angostura bitters.Both drinks were like soda drinks.Food arrived fairly quick considering that most other customers were just having drinks.

address: 1 Maritime Square #01-64, HarbourFront Centre Singapore 099253 Singapore
comment: The two stars are giving to the drinks... because the pasta and pizza are so bad. Think they used frozen pizza, and just heat it, and the bottom was not even dry enough... can you imagine eating wet dough?

address: 10 Pasir Panjang Rd Mapletree Business City Singapore 117438 Singapore
comment: 7.90 for the non-vegetarian buffet and 6 for the vegetarian buffet! Both come with a free cup of water. The meats change from day to day, they have about 4 veg choices, 2 kinds of briyani, 4 types of curry, poppadum, prata, soup, buttermilk. Veg choices range from brinjal to fried potato strips (like fries). It's all free flow since it's a buffet.You pay for the variety and going for a second round I guess. It's quite cheap, considering the last few times I went to an Indian food stall, I am usually charged 4+ dollars for briyani, 2 veg, one meat and curry over my briyani, and much smaller portions.Taste-wise, it's all like quite above average, nothing tastes bad. Better than some buffets, and great price. And I just like having the choice!Of course, they cater to the working-lunch crowd, so no one does eat so much :P Maybe that's why they can charge 7.90. But although people don't stay for long, the place is still really packed! It's hard to get a seat past 1230, though it eases very quickly around 1. Don't worry about being left with leftovers, they replace frequently.

address: 10 Pasir Panjang Rd Mapletree Business City Singapore 117438 Singapore
comment: Prata Prata seemed doomed for failure when it just opened up at Maple Tree Business City. They say ""Better a dry crust eaten in peace than a house filled with feasting--and conflict."" Prata Prata's dry crusted prata kept the people away, so you could have a peaceful lunch here. Other food options were expensive and not popular as well. But then they came up with the idea to have a buffet lunch. $7,90 for 4 choices of veggies, 3 choices of meats, 2 choices of rice and unlimited prata! And you also get a free glass of water! Since then it became a house fulled with feasting and conflict as well. When I say conflict I mean fighting for an empty space to sit, complaining about dirty tables and for prata, because the poor guy just can't keep up with the demand. Best is to enjoy this lunch buffet before 12:30 so you can feast in peace

address: Blk 115, Bukit Merah View #01-78 Bukit Merah View Food Centre Singapore 151115 Singapore
comment: Have you been here? If you haven't, please dedicate one night to coming here!Spent a Friday night having YTF here, and it is to die for. We spent about $20 for two people, and we were so stuffed we could barely walk.This place opens at 11/12 at night, and before they open, everyone sits around like vultures waiting for the auntie to turn on the signboard for opening. They have a myriad of YTF items, like intestines, fish maw, pork belly, all sorts of veggies et al, and they dump a liberal amount of fried ikan bilis into your soup before serving, which incidentally, is the BEST soup base I've ever tried.I don't take their noodles, but they sprinkle fried lard on top of them. You likey?Pro tip: When you queue for your YTF, get your friend to pick the items. Do not pick the items together, as you will have to wait ONE hour for your turn. Collaboration is key here!

address: Blk 115, Bukit Merah View #01-78 Bukit Merah View Food Centre Singapore 151115 Singapore
comment: Coming to this Yong Tau Foo (random food items you can pick served with noodles and soup) place is certainly an interesting experience.For starters there's the opening time - midnight to 3am (even though this isn't near a nightlife place). However these times are not set in stone - we arrived at 12:30am and the food was only ready around 1am. The advantage of this timing is that the hawker centre is really empty - only a few random drink stalls were open, and only the one beside the yong tau foo seemed to be going at full steam.And then there's the confusing system of ordering - there's no guide for first-timers and the staff are a bit grumpy and assume everyone knows what the system is; it doesn't help that some of the information online (which I'd read to prepare for my visit) is wrong.As far as I can tell, the way the ordering system works is this: there're 2 queues. The first is on the right for you to select what items you want, and the second is on the left for you to send in your order. These queues work independently - so you should come with at least one other person so both of you can queue in either queue at the same time. Once it's the turn of the person in the left (order) queue, your order will be taken and you should say if you want noodles or bee hoon (or neither), if you want vegetables, if you want your order done dry or with soup (everyone had it dry so that's presumably better), if you want pork oil and if you want chili and/or sweet sauce (presumably only for dry orders). And don't block the exit to the stall because the lady will periodically emerge with huge steaming bowls and place them on a tray on the table outside the stall.There's a huge variety of ingredients here - the largest I've ever seen at a yong tau foo stall. And you don't find many elsewhere: pork belly, intestines, luncheon meat, squid, cuttlefish, stuffed mushrooms and your usual things (like lady's finger stuffed with fish paste).Their soup is quite spicy on the default setting, so you might want to ask for no added chili (it's even spicier than the chili sauce in noodles, since the man cuts chili padi into it)The pork oil, crispy lard, sweet and chili sauces all combine to explode in your mouth in a harmonious blend.At 1:30am the first queue had died and at 2:10am there were only two people in either queue. So if you can wait a bit it's better to come a bit later. And it's not like food will run out - some things which had run out were replenished even at 2am.This place could definitely use a process improvement consultant and more signs, but if you're hungry and in the area you could do worse than drop by.

address: Blk 115, Bukit Merah View #01-78 Bukit Merah View Food Centre Singapore 151115 Singapore
comment: Soup base is sweat! Good variety for supper, cheap and generous

not quite magical in my books yet.but i do like what they are trying to do here.will definitely support them as long as they can get their booking system working, without one hour glitches.kudos to them for the complimentary prosecco for the painful booking process some, like myself, had to endure.never been to their smaller old location just down across the road.this spanking new stand alone building with plentiful private parking right up front is definitely a good thing!lovely space within with great view of the open kitchen and lots of natural light coming through the full length windows also.i do like that they will not wait for you if you are late.if you are one of those tardy ones, you can only pick up from where the meal is at when you walk in.so don't be late!don't expect too much in terms of service.they might bring you a bottle of water and give you a first pour but the rest is up to you.the friendly vibes was good.a young team, promising.a menu that's showcasing local produce and flavours whilst injecting a complexity and finesse for the sharper, critical gourmet foodie tongues.some misses but mostly above par.we all need some magic in our lives and you can't really go wrong if you magically score a pair of seats to dine here!p.s. chef marcus' menu will be extended till end of november 2021.

address: Star Vista 1 Vista Exchange Green Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: Yes yes yes, it's a chain, but it is a reliable chain with everything you're looking for: reasonably-priced food, consistently-good quality, speed and service.What can you get here? Kopitiam breakfast, local drinks, desserts and best of all, wanton mee! I love how the noodles are springy. The flavors of selection 5 is unbeatable. Spicy, sweet and a little tangy. And. Best of all, you can get all fried wantons!! Remember to get a scoop of mayonnaise to accompany the wantons! The soup is good too, not bland or full of MSG at other places. Turnover is really fast and during lunch time we sometimes have a communal table. A comfort food I crave, price is a little higher than hawker center but with the comfort of speed and air con, that's all worth it!!

address: Star Vista 1 Vista Exchange Green Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: Located at B1 of the Star Vista, Pon Tian is super convenient for a quick tasty lunch after church service. Had the same Wan Ton noodles at different branches of Pon Tian, but none seems to have the same consistent quality at this branch. Love the combo sauce option which includes the dark sauce chili and tomato, extremely flavourful and coupled with delicious fried wan ton dipped in mayo!

address: Star Vista 1 Vista Exchange Green Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: Tasty and above average, but the portion is really small. The Char Siew is roasted right, tender and not too salty. We also have the Tau Suan dessert, a bit sweet and below average.

address: Star Vista 1 Vista Exchange Green Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: Getting a good plate of wan tan mee in Singapore is pretty rare (compared to Penang style wan tan mee). Pontian makes up for this rarity. Their noodles are al dante, just the way it should be. Their sauce has the right amount of saltiness and they add plenty to coat all your noodles. For $4, you get a good amount of noodles with a few crispy wan tan AND a bowl of soup WITH more wan tans. This particular Pontian is located right across from Cold Storage in Star Vista. It has limited seatings but high turnover. It is a nice option if you want something quick and cheap. I highly recommend this place to wan tan mee lovers, especially those who have experienced Penang style wan tan mee.

address: Star Vista 1 Vista Exchange Green Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: I'd been craving a good plate of wan tan mee since returning from 4 years in the U.S., and I was unsure whether I'd be able to source a good one outside of Malaysia (where I was born). Well, Pontian to the rescue! It was a damn good bowl of chewy/al dente noodles, which I ordered with extra spice - only wish the wontons were steamed/boiled as opposed to fried. Will definitely return!

Went to a business dinner here and was AMAZED.  Easily one of the top restaurants I've ever been to in the world.  Chef Patrick came out to discuss the menu and make recommendations before we ordered.  The dishes were served family style so I was able to try many different items and all were delicious.  The deserts were mini works of art and did not disappoint.  Not sure when I will be back in Singapore but rest assured, I will eat there when I am.

Great pate and rilettes!  ....as one would expect from the former Bistro Du Vin chef.  Everything we tried was tasty. The service was also great, got there on a Friday with no reservation and did their best to accommodate us, first inviting us at the bar upstairs for a drink and a small bite, as we were waiting for a table. Amazing! Will definitely be back.

Chef Patrick Heuberger has taken over the old Au Petit Salut, and he has lengthened and broadened the menu, and improved on the honest cooking. The food is very good and portions are generous, so a large group would gain by sharing appetisers. The charcuterie dishes (duck rillettes, pâté en croûte, beef tongue) are commendable, but the pig brain is really outstanding. Among the mains, the mustard rabbit is superb, and the stuffed quail is also scrumptious. Service is pleasant - chef Patrick regularly visits the dining room, and the French maître d' is very helpful in recommending dishes or unusual wines. The only bémol is the local staff - friendly but blurred. For instance, for our 'tah pow' they didn't pack the excellent sauce (there was an abundant amount left) and forgot to give it to us!

a tout i am not but touting them, i am!now, more about Ah-too?old location, new branding?new restaurant, veteran chef!for those who have dined at au petit slaut before, you will be very familiar with the layout here, perhaps a little more chillax now than before.menu is more varied but you will also notice a similar slant to it.they have been rather packed since their opening and that i think has stretched their service team to the brink of inadequate service.if you can bare with, slow..............service then your palates will be in for a treat!i would much rather have my bread basket filled with toasted bakes but they were good enough for the duck rillettes that i ordered as a starter and both were in fact good to eat even on it's own.a taste of the frothy lobster bisque with give you a cappuccinoess lightness contrasted with the depth of a strong, hearty, crustacean creamy base layer.the white asparagus, that will incur a supplement, fulfilled it's aphrodisiac role more than a gastronomical one.the main i had was a crispy black pudding and it transported me back to that very day in edinburgh when i first laid tongue on it!but now, to a much desired end result.gastronomical heaven in black and i'm definitely going back!it may not look like much but the perfect crisp gently peels away to reveal a soft, smooth, vulnerable, delectably minced mix.it's not gamey at all, no repulsion whatsoever, just pure attraction!simply seated on a bed of apple sauce to further tickle the palate.the oven roasted french chicken with 40 garlic came steaming hot in a claypot.just be careful not to burn your most valuable asset whilst eating!again, it does not look like much but the tenderness of it all will justify your decision to share this with another(only available for two pax).so maybe come in a bigger group and indulge.i'm not a big fan of tenderloin cut but if you must have your beef and eat it.pay the +$10 supplement and steak out!as it is a three course set lunch for $42++, be sure to pace yourself suitably for the sweet ending.in my case i had the truffle brie, not sweet but sweet!i guess they have to think about some crackers to accompany it?all you get is a singular slab of it.well, i don't really care to have any but am just used to all the condiments that come with my cheese plate most of the time i order one.otherwise, head straight for the super dark chocolate pot!it's 70% and a thick mousse in texture.there is a reason why it is their specialty!having cut his teeth elsewhere with various experts in their field, patrick has come back stronger and it shows in their food.i think his personable ways will be the trump card and further his chances of success with atout!
